description: Examination of social welfare within a historical context, addressing the economic, political, social and ideological influences that have shaped the social welfare system and programs. Critical study of the income maintenance system in the United States as a response to the problems of inequality of opportunity and income, poverty, and income security; consideration of alternative approaches with discussion of the social worker's role in the system. 3 undergraduate hours. 4 graduate hours.
label: Social Welfare Pol and Svcs
sectionRegistrationNotes: Not intended for students with Freshman or Sophomore class standing. Restricted to Undergrad - Urbana-Champaign.
